cleaned_text: [Psychopharmacology](/wiki/Biological_psychology:_Psychopharmacology) ( [Index](/wiki/Index_of_biological_psychology), [Outline](/wiki/Outline_of_biological_psychology)) - This article is about lithium as a medication. For more general information on lithium as a chemical, see [Lithium](/wiki/Lithium). | is commonly used as a [psychiatric](/wiki/Psychiatry) [medication](/wiki/Medication). A number of chemical [salts](/wiki/Salt_(chemistry)) of [lithium](/wiki/Lithium) are used medically as [mood-stabilizing](/wiki/Mood_stabilizer) [drugs](/wiki/Medication), primarily in the treatment of [bipolar disorder](/wiki/Bipolar_disorder), where they have a role in the treatment of [depression](/wiki/Clinical_depression) and particularly of [mania](/wiki/Mania), both acutely and in the long term. As a mood stabilizer, lithium is probably more effective in preventing mania than depression, and reduces the risk of suicide in bipolar patients. [[1]](#cite_note-1) In depression alone (unipolar disorder), lithium can be used to augment other antidepressants. Lithium carbonate (Li2CO3), sold under several trade names, is the most commonly prescribed, while [lithium citrate](/wiki/Lithium_citrate) (Li3C6H5O7) is also used in conventional pharmacological treatments. Lithium sulfate (Li2SO4) has been presented as an alternative.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Psychology_Wiki:Citing_sources)] Upon ingestion, lithium becomes widely distributed in the [central nervous system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system) and interacts with a number of [receptors](/wiki/Receptor_(biochemistry)), [norepinephrine](/wiki/Norepinephrine) (noradrenaline) release and increasing [serotonin](/wiki/Serotonin) synthesis. Medical uses[ ] Lithium treatment is used to treat [mania](/wiki/Mania) in [bipolar disorder](/wiki/Bipolar_disorder). Initially, lithium is often used in conjunction with [antipsychotic drugs](/wiki/Antipsychotic_drugs) as it can take up to a month for it to have an effect. Lithium is also used as [prophylaxis](/wiki/Prophylaxis) for [depression](/wiki/Depression_(mood)) and mania in bipolar disorder. It is sometimes used for other psychiatric disorders, such as cycloid psychosis and [major depressive disorder](/wiki/Major_depressive_disorder). [[2]](#cite_note-2) [[3]](#cite_note-3) Lithium possesses a very important antisuicidal effect not shown in other stabilizing medications such as antiseizure drugs. [[4]](#cite_note-ReferenceA-4) [[5]](#cite_note-5) Nonpsychiatric applications are limited; however, its use is well established in the prophylaxis of some headaches related to [cluster headaches](/wiki/Cluster_headache) (trigeminal autonomic cephalgias), particularly hypnic headache. An Italian pilot study in humans conducted in 2005-06 suggested lithium may improve outcomes in the [neurodegenerative disease](/wiki/Neurodegenerative_disease) double-blind, placebo-controlled trial comparing the safety and efficacy of lithium in combination with riluzole for treatment of ALS failed to demonstrate a benefit as compared to a combination therapy over riluzole alone. [[8]](#cite_note-8) Lithium is sometimes used as an augmenting agent to increase the benefits of standard drugs used for unipolar depression. Lithium treatment was previously considered to be unsuitable for children; however, more recent studies show its effectiveness for treatment of early-onset bipolar disorder in children as young as eight. The required dosage (15-20 mg per kg of body weight) is slightly less than the toxic level, requiring blood levels of lithium to be monitored closely during treatment. To prescribe the correct dosage, the patient's entire medical history, both physical and psychological, is sometimes taken into consideration. The starting dosage of lithium should be 400-600 mg given at night and increased weekly depending on serum monitoring. [[9]](#cite_note-9) Those who use lithium should receive regular serum level tests and should monitor thyroid and kidney function for abnormalities, as it interferes with the regulation of [sodium](/wiki/Sodium) and [water](/wiki/Water) levels in the body, and can cause [dehydration](/wiki/Dehydration). Dehydration, which is compounded by heat, can result in increasing lithium levels. The dehydration is due to lithium inhibition of the action of [antidiuretic hormone](/wiki/Antidiuretic_hormone), which normally enables the kidney to reabsorb water from urine. This causes an inability to concentrate urine, leading to consequent loss of body water and thirst. [[10]](#cite_note-10) High doses of [haloperidol](/wiki/Haloperidol), [fluphenazine](/wiki/Fluphenazine), or [flupenthixol](/wiki/Flupenthixol) may be hazardous when used with lithium; irreversible toxic encephalopathy has been reported. [[11]](#cite_note-11) Lithium salts have a narrow therapeutic/toxic ratio, so should not be prescribed unless facilities for monitoring [plasma](/wiki/Blood_plasma) concentrations are available. Patients should be carefully selected. Doses are adjusted to achieve plasma concentrations of 0.4 [[12]](#cite_note-12) [[13]](#cite_note-13) to 1.2 mmol Li+/l (lower end of the range for maintenance therapy and elderly patients, higher end for pediatric patients) on samples taken 12 hours after the preceding dose. Overdosage, usually with plasma concentrations over 1.5 mmol Li+/l, may be fatal, and toxic effects [dysarthria](/wiki/Dysarthria), [nystagmus](/wiki/Pathologic_nystagmus), [renal impairment](/wiki/Renal_failure), confusion, and [convulsions](/wiki/Convulsion). If these potentially hazardous signs occur, treatment should be stopped, plasma lithium concentrations redetermined, and steps taken to reverse lithium toxicity. Lithium toxicity is compounded by sodium depletion. Concurrent use of [diuretics](/wiki/Diuretics) that inhibit the uptake of sodium by the distal tubule (e.g. thiazides) is hazardous and should be avoided because this can cause increased resorption of lithium in the proximal convoluted tubule, leading to elevated, potentially toxic levels. In mild cases, withdrawal of lithium and administration of generous amounts of sodium and fluid will reverse the toxicity. Plasma concentrations in excess of 2.5 mmol Li+/l are usually associated with serious toxicity requiring emergency treatment. When toxic concentrations are reached, there may be a delay of one or two days before maximum toxicity occurs. In long-term use, therapeutic concentrations of lithium have been thought to cause [histological](/wiki/Histology) and functional changes in the kidney. The significance of such changes is not clear, but is of sufficient concern to discourage long-term use of lithium unless it is definitely indicated. Doctors may change a bipolar patient's medication from lithium to another mood-stabilizing drug, such as [valproate](/wiki/Valproic_acid) (Depakote), if problems with the kidneys arise. An important potential consequence of long-term lithium use is the development of renal [diabetes insipidus](/wiki/Diabetes_insipidus) (inability to concentrate urine). Patients should therefore be maintained on lithium treatment after three to five years only if, on assessment, benefit persists[ [citation needed](/wiki/Psychology_Wiki:Citing_sources)]. Conventional and sustained-release tablets are available. Preparations vary widely in [bioavailability](/wiki/Bioavailability), and a change in the formulation used requires the same precautions as initiation of treatment. There are few reasons to prefer any one simple salt of lithium; the carbonate has been the more widely used, but the citrate is also available. Lithium may be used as a treatment of seborrhoeic dermatitis (lithium gluconate 8% gel)[ [citation needed](/wiki/Psychology_Wiki:Citing_sources)]. In addition, lithium has been shown to increase production of white blood cells in the [bone marrow](/wiki/Bone_marrow) and might be indicated in patients suffering from leukopenia. [[14]](#cite_note-14) A limited amount of evidence suggests lithium may contribute to treatment of substance abuse for some dual-disorder patients. [[15]](#cite_note-15) [[16]](#cite_note-16) [[17]](#cite_note-17) In 2009, Japanese researchers at Oita University reported low levels of naturally occurring lithium in drinking water supplies reduced suicide rates. [[18]](#cite_note-18) A previous report had found similar data in the American state of [Texas](/wiki/Texas). [[19]](#cite_note-19) In response, psychiatrist Peter Kramer raised the hypothetical possibility of adding lithium to drinking water as a mineral supplement rather than as a therapeutic drug. [[20]](#cite_note-20) (The therapeutic dosage of lithium carbonate (tablets and capsules) or citrate (liquid) "usually ranges from 900 - 1,200 mg/day" and is adjusted according to patient response and blood levels. [[21]](#cite_note-21)) This is analogous to [niacin](/wiki/Niacin), where a low dose in multivitamin pills is taken as a vitamin supplement to prevent the niacin deficiency disease [pellagra](/wiki/Pellagra), but a high dose is prescribed as a therapeutic drug to raise [high-density lipoprotein](/wiki/High-density_lipoprotein) ("good" cholesterol) levels. Side effects[ ] The most common side effects are an overall dazed feeling and a fine [tremor](/wiki/Tremor) of hands. These side effects are generally present during the length of the treatment, but can sometimes disappear in certain patients. Other common side effects, such as nausea and headache, can be generally remedied by a higher intake of water. Lithium unbalances electrolytes; to counteract this, increased water intake is recommended.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Psychology_Wiki:Citing_sources)] According to an Australian study, "The incidence of [hypothyroidism](/wiki/Hypothyroidism) is six-fold higher in patients on lithium as compared to the general population. Hypothyroidism in turn increases the likelihood of developing clinical depression." [[22]](#cite_note-22) Lithium is known to be responsible for 1-2kg of weight gain. [[23]](#cite_note-23) Weight gain may be a source of low self esteem for the clinically depressed. [[24]](#cite_note-24) Because lithium competes with the receptors for the [antidiuretic hormone](/wiki/Antidiuretic_hormone) in the kidney, it increases water output into the urine, a condition called nephrogenic [diabetes insipidus](/wiki/Diabetes_insipidus). Clearance of lithium by the kidneys is usually successful with certain diuretic medications, including [amiloride](/wiki/Amiloride) and triamterene. [[25]](#cite_note-25) It increases the appetite and thirst ("polydypsia") and be corrected by treatment with [thyroxine](/wiki/Thyroxine). Lithium is also believed to permanently affect renal function, although this does not appear to be common. [[31]](#cite_note-31) Lithium is a well-known cause of [downbeat nystagmus](/wiki/Physiologic_nystagmus#Types), [[32]](#cite_note-32) which may be permanent or require several months of abstinence for improvement. [[33]](#cite_note-33) Most side effects of lithium are dose-dependent. The lowest effective dose is used to limit the risk of side effects. Teratogenicity[ ] Lithium is also a [teratogen](/wiki/Teratogen), causing birth defects in a small number of newborn babies. [[34]](#cite_note-Shepard-2002-34) [Case reports](/wiki/Case_report) and several [retrospective studies](/wiki/Retrospective_cohort_study) have demonstrated possible increases in the rate of a congenital heart defect known as Ebstein's anomaly, if taken during a woman's pregnancy. [[35]](#cite_note-pmid18982835-35) As a consequence, fetal echocardiography is routinely performed in pregnant women taking lithium to exclude the possibility of cardiac anomalies. [Lamotrigine](/wiki/Lamotrigine) seems to be a possible alternative to lithium in pregnant women. [[35]](#cite_note-pmid18982835-35) [Gabapentin](/wiki/Gabapentin) [[36]](#cite_note-pmid12791334-36) and [clonazepam](/wiki/Clonazepam) [[37]](#cite_note-pmid11340418-37) are also indicated as antipanic medications during the childbearing years and during [pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy). [Valproic acid](/wiki/Valproic_acid) and [carbamazepine](/wiki/Carbamazepine) also tend to be associated with teratogenicity. Dehydration[ ] Dehydration in patients taking lithium salts can be very hazardous, especially when combined with lithium induced nephrogenic [diabetes insipidus](/wiki/Diabetes_insipidus) with polyuria. Such situations include preoperative fluid regimen or other fluid inaccessibility, warm weather conditions, sporting events, and hiking. Another danger is that rapid hydration may very quickly produce hyponatremia with its danger of toxic lithium concentrations in plasma. Overdose[ ] Lithium toxicity may occur in persons taking excessive amounts either accidentally or intentionally on an acute basis or in patients who accumulate high levels during ongoing chronic therapy. The manifestations include nausea, [emesis](/wiki/Emesis), diarrhea, [asthenia](/wiki/Asthenia), [ataxia](/wiki/Ataxia), confusion, lethargy, [polyuria](/wiki/Polyuria), seizures and coma. Other toxic effects of lithium include coarse tremor, [muscle twitching](/wiki/Muscle_twitching), [convulsions](/wiki/Convulsion) and [renal failure](/wiki/Renal_failure). [[38]](#cite_note-38) People who survive a poisoning episode may develop persistent neurotoxicity. Several authors have described a "Syndrome of Irreversible Lithium-Effected Neurotoxicity" (SILENT), associated with episodes of acute lithium toxicity or long-term treatment within the appropriate dosage range. Symptoms are said to include [cerebellar](/wiki/Cerebellum) dysfunction. [[39]](#cite_note-39) Measurement in body fluids[ ] Lithium concentrations in whole blood, plasma, serum or urine may be measured using instrumental techniques as a guide to therapy, to confirm the diagnosis in potential poisoning victims or to assist in the forensic investigation in a case of fatal overdosage. Serum lithium concentrations are usually in the 0.5-1.3 mmol/l range in well-controlled patients, but may increase to 1.8-2.5 mmol/l in patients who accumulate the drug over time and to 3-10 mmol/l in victims of acute overdosage. [[40]](#cite_note-40) action[ ] Unlike other [psychoactive drugs](/wiki/Psychoactive_drugs), Li+ typically produces no obvious psychotropic effects (such as [euphoria](/wiki/Euphoria_(emotion))) in normal individuals at therapeutic concentrations. Li+ possibly produces its effects by interacting with the transport of monovalent or divalent [cations](/wiki/Cations) in [neurons](/wiki/Neurons). However, because it is a poor substrate at the [sodium pump](/wiki/Sodium_pump), it cannot maintain a [membrane potential](/wiki/Membrane_potential) and only sustains a small gradient across biological membranes.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Psychology_Wiki:Citing_sources)] Li+ is similar enough to Na+ that under experimental conditions, it can replace Na+ for production of a single [action potential](/wiki/Action_potential) in [neurons](/wiki/Neuron).[ [citation needed](/wiki/Psychology_Wiki:Citing_sources)] Recent research suggests three different mechanisms which may or may not act together to deliver the mood-stabilizing effect of this ion. [[42]](#cite_note-42) The excitatory [neurotransmitter](/wiki/Neurotransmitter) [glutamate](/wiki/Glutamate) could be involved in the effect of lithium as other mood stabilizers, such as valproate and [lamotrigine](/wiki/Lamotrigine), exert influence over glutamate, suggesting a possible biological explanation for mania.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Psychology_Wiki:Citing_sources)] The other mechanisms by which lithium might help to regulate mood include the alteration of [gene expression](/wiki/Gene_expression). [[43]](#cite_note-43) Lithium may also increase the release of [serotonin](/wiki/Serotonin) by neurons in the brain. [[44]](#cite_note-44) In vitro studies performed on serotonergic neurons from rat [raphe nuclei](/wiki/Raphe_nuclei) have shown that when these neurons are treated with lithium, [serotonin](/wiki/Serotonin) release is enhanced during a [depolarization](/wiki/Depolarization) compared to no lithium treatment and the same depolarization. [[45]](#cite_note-45) An unrelated mechanism of action has been proposed in which lithium deactivates the GSK3 enzyme. [[46]](#cite_note-pmid8710892-46) This enzyme normally [phosphorylates](/wiki/Phosphorylation) the Rev-Erb transcription factor protein stabilizing it against degradation. Rev-Erb in turn represses BMAL1, a component of the [circadian clock](/wiki/Circadian_clock). Hence, lithium by inhibiting GSK3 causes the degradation of Rev-Erb and increases the expression of BMAL which dampens the circadian clock [[47]](#cite_note-pmid16484495-47) Through this mechanism, lithium is able to block the resetting of the "master clock" inside the brain; as a result, the body's natural cycle is disrupted. When the cycle is disrupted, the routine schedules of many functions (metabolism, sleep, body temperature) are disturbed. Lithium may thus restore normal brain function after it is disrupted in some people. Several authors proposed that pAp-phosphatase could be one of the therapeutic targets of lithium. [[48]](#cite_note-48) [[49]](#cite_note-49) This hypothesis was supported by the low Ki of lithium for human pAp-phosphatase compatible within the range of therapeutic concentrations of lithium in the plasma of patients (0.8-1 mM). Importantly, the Ki of human pAp-phosphatase is ten times lower than that of GSK3 (glycogen synthase kinase 3). Inhibition of pAp-phosphatase by lithium leads to increased levels of pAp (3-5 phosphoadenosine phosphate), which was shown to inhibit PARP-1 [[50]](#cite_note-50) Another mechanism proposed in 2007 is that lithium may interact with [nitric oxide](/wiki/Nitric_oxide) (NO) signalling pathway in the central nervous system, which plays a crucial role in the neural plasticity. The NO system could be involved in the antidepressant effect of lithium in the Porsolt forced swimming test in mice. [[51]](#cite_note-pmid17728109-51) [[52]](#cite_note-pmid19166880-52) It was also reported that NMDA receptor blockage augments antidepressant-like effects of lithium in the mouse forced swimming test, [[53]](#cite_note-pmid19351802-53) indicating the possible involvement of NMDA receptor/NO signaling in the action of lithium in this animal model of [learned helplessness](/wiki/Learned_helplessness). [Lithium](/wiki/Lithium) treatment has been found to inhibit the enzyme inositol monophosphatase, leading to higher levels of inositol triphosphate. [[54]](#cite_note-pmid9588758-54) This effect was enhanced further with an inositol triphosphate [reuptake inhibitor](/wiki/Reuptake_inhibitor). [Inositol](/wiki/Inositol) disruptions have been linked to memory impairment and [depression](/wiki/Depression_(mood)). History[ ] Lithium was first used in the 19th century as a treatment for gout after scientists discovered, at least in the laboratory, lithium could dissolve [uric acid](/wiki/Uric_acid) crystals isolated from the kidneys. The levels of lithium needed to dissolve urate in the body, however, were toxic. [[55]](#cite_note-pmid_18789369-55) Because of prevalent theories linking excess uric acid to a range of disorders, including depressive and manic disorders, Carl Lange in [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark) [[56]](#cite_note-56) and William Alexander Hammond in [New York](/wiki/New_York) [[57]](#cite_note-57) used lithium to treat mania from the 1870s onwards, though use in the form of spring waters to treat mania were reported in ancient Roman and Greek times.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Psychology_Wiki:Citing_sources)] By the turn of the 20th century, this use of lithium was largely abandoned, according to Susan Greenfield, due to the reluctance of the pharmaceutical industry to invest in a drug that could not be patented. [[58]](#cite_note-58) As accumulating knowledge indicated a role for excess sodium intake in [hypertension](/wiki/Hypertension) and [heart disease](/wiki/Heart_disease), lithium salts were prescribed to patients for use as a replacement for dietary table salt ( [sodium chloride](/wiki/Sodium_chloride)). This practice was discontinued in 1949 when reports of side effects and deaths were published, leading to a ban of lithium sales. [[55]](#cite_note-pmid_18789369-55) The use of lithium salts to treat mania was rediscovered by the Australian psychiatrist John Cade in 1949. Cade was injecting rodents with urine extracts taken from schizophrenic patients, in an attempt to isolate a metabolic compound which might be causing mental symptoms. Since uric acid in gout was known to be psychoactive ( [adenosine receptors](/wiki/Adenosine_receptors) on neurons are stimulated by it; [caffeine](/wiki/Caffeine) blocks them), Cade needed soluble urate for a control. He used lithium urate, already known to be the most soluble urate compound, and observed it caused the rodents to be tranquilized. Cade traced the effect to the lithium ion itself. Soon, Cade proposed lithium salts as [tranquilizers](/wiki/Tranquilizer), and soon succeeded in controlling mania in chronically hospitalized patients with them. This was one of the first successful applications of a drug to treat mental illness, and it opened the door for the development of medicines for other mental problems in the next decades. [[59]](#cite_note-59) The rest of the world was slow to adopt this treatment, largely because of deaths which resulted from even relatively minor overdosing, including those reported from use of [lithium chloride](/wiki/Lithium_chloride) as a substitute for table salt. Largely through the research and other efforts of Denmark's Mogens Schou and Paul Baastrup in Europe, [[55]](#cite_note-pmid_18789369-55) and Samuel Gershon and Baron Shopsin in the U.S., this resistance was slowly overcome. The application of lithium in manic illness was approved by the United States [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) in 1970. [[60]](#cite_note-60) In 1974, this application was extended to its use as a preventive agent for manic-depressive illness. Lithium has become a part of Western popular culture. Characters in Pi, Premonition, Stardust Memories, American Psycho, "Garden State", and An Unmarried Woman all take lithium. Sirius XM Satellite Radio in North America has a 1990s alternative rock station called Lithium, and several songs refer to the use of lithium as a mood stabilizer. These include: "Lithium Lips" by Mac Lethal, "Equilibrium met Sirenia, Sunset", from the album Mercury Falling by Sting, [[61]](#cite_note-61) and "Lithium" by Thin White Rope. Use in 7 Up[ ] As with cocaine in Coca-Cola, lithium was widely marketed as one of a number of patent medicine products popular in the late-19th and early-20th centuries, and was the medicinal ingredient of a refreshment beverage. Charles Leiper Grigg, who launched his St. Louis-based company, The Howdy Corporation invented a formula for a lemon-lime soft drink in 1920. The product, originally named "Bib-Label Lithiated Lemon-Lime Soda", was launched two weeks before the Wall Street Crash of 1929. [[62]](#cite_note-dpsuhist-62) It contained the [mood stabiliser](/wiki/Mood_stabiliser) [lithium citrate](/wiki/Lithium_citrate), and was one of a number of patent medicine products popular in the late-19th and early-20th centuries. [[63]](#cite_note-63) Its name was soon changed to 7 Up; all American beverage makers were forced to remove lithium in 1948.
